title: 110_hr852
content: The Act may be cited as the "Consumer Telephone Records Protection Act of 2007". The findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that unauthorized access to customer telephone records can occur through various means, including pretexting and online account breaches. Many customers do not access their online accounts, making it easier for unauthorized individuals to gain access to their phone records and call logs. SEC. 3. UNFAIR AND DECEPTIVE ACTS AND PRACTICES IN OBTAINING CONFIDENTIAL PHONE RECORDS INFORMATION. Prohibition on obtaining confidential phone records information under false pretenses includes making false statements to employees or customers of a covered entity, providing false documents, or accessing customer accounts without authorization. Prohibition on selling or transferring confidential phone records information without customer authorization, except as permitted by law. Exceptions specified in section 222(d) of the Communications Act of 1934 apply for the use of such information by covered entities. Prohibition on purchasing or receiving confidential phone records information without customer authorization, except as permitted by law. Exceptions specified in section 222(d) of the Communications Act of 1934 apply for the use of such information by covered entities. The prohibition on purchasing or receiving confidential phone records information without customer authorization applies to covered entities as defined in section 7. SEC. 4 states that the law does not apply to authorized investigative, protective, or intelligence activities of law enforcement agencies. SEC. 5 requires telecommunications carriers to notify customers. SEC. 5 amends the Communications Act to require telecommunications carriers to notify customers of any unauthorized disclosure of customer information. SEC. 6 involves enforcement by the Federal Trade Commission. SEC. 6 states that violations of section 3 will be treated as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act, giving the Commission the power to enforce compliance regardless of jurisdictional tests. The Act defines "confidential phone records information" as data related to services used by a customer of a covered entity, provided solely due to the relationship between the entity and the customer. The Act defines "confidential phone records information" as data related to services provided by a covered entity to a customer, with the covered entity being a telecommunications carrier or provider of IP-enabled voice service. A customer is defined as an individual or entity receiving a product or service from the covered entity. IP-enabled voice service refers to real-time voice communications transmitted through customer premises equipment using TCP/IP protocol, with interconnection capability to the public switched telephone network.
